{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3004734,"name":"aidanw02","username":"aidanw02","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aidanw02/{size}/167211_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-08T16:02:42.005Z","cooked":"

We were wondering what other teams cargo diameter is at correct pressure. Ours is measuring about 9 1/4". Currently we‚Äôre still waiting for our pressure gauge to come in, but have filled the cargo up until it‚Äôs definitely over pressurized and it doesn‚Äôt seem to be growing any larger.

I thought it‚Äôs weird that the manual says the cargo is 9 1/2" instead of ~ 9 1/2".

Section 5.7
CARGO is 9¬Ω in. (~24 cm) in diameter, weighs 9¬Ω oz. (~270 g), and has a fuzz surface.
CARGO is inflated to 3¬Ω psi. ¬±¬Ω psi.

What diameter are you guys getting with your cargo?

All the cargo I have measured has been 9.25ish. Granted we only have 2 currently. Waiting on more.

yup, 9.25" diameter, and it doesn‚Äôt change appreciably with pressure, past about 2psi

Have you seen any expansion of similar inflated game pieces in previous years as they get used throughout competition?

I can‚Äôt recall any similar game pieces. The closest might be 2010. The rubber balls with very elastic skin, as used in 2019, and the large balls with a cloth bag around an elastic bladder in 2008-2014, are not really the same as the 2022 game piece.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-02-08T18:47:46.101Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":313,"readers_count":312,"score":62.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":402473,"topic_slug":"cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure","display_username":"Jim Forbes","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":33001,"username":"aidanw02","name":"aidanw02","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aidanw02/{size}/167211_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure/402473/5","custom_user_title":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3004863,"name":"waialua3:59","username":"waialua359","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/waialua359/{size}/676_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-08T19:15:32.538Z","cooked":"

As I‚Äôve been told many times after learning the hard way in 2020. Design around the variations (different psi and worn out game pieces). I dont have much confidence in the pressure gauge regulation at events, and I‚Äôll bet it‚Äôll vary from event to event.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-02-08T20:39:09.717Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":280,"readers_count":279,"score":151.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":402473,"topic_slug":"cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure","display_username":"waialua3:59","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2254,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure/402473/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3004878,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-08T19:41:02.325Z","cooked":"
MrForbes:

doesn‚Äôt change appreciably with pressure, past about 2psi

Stupid question I should know the answer to, but don‚Äôt have a complex enough mental model.

Would atmospheric pressure at different alititudes come into play here?

image810√ó797 41.5 KB

Or, maybe asked differently‚Ä¶ does the spec‚Äôed inflation PSI refer to some absolute measurement that won‚Äôt vary as altitude/weather changes, or is it relative to outside atmospheric pressure?

I really feel like I should know this answer, but I‚Äôm drawing a blank on how to even think about it.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-02-08T19:41:02.325Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":262,"readers_count":261,"score":77.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":402473,"topic_slug":"cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/2/b/2b37eb4534d0fc3167769e017e0e1446cb8b46f8.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure/402473/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3004879,"name":"Jim Forbes","username":"MrForbes","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrforbes/{size}/165505_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-08T19:47:44.952Z","cooked":"

good question‚Ä¶I can take a wild guess.

If the ball is elastic, then it will expand when going to a higher elevation (lower atmospheric pressure). The gauge pressure may not change much.

If the ball is inelastic, then the absolute pressure in the ball will stay the same, but atmospheric pressure will drop with increased elevation, so the gauge should read higher. The spec‚Äôd pressure is a relative pressure reading. So when you bring a ball from your home in San Diego, to play in Denver, you‚Äôll need to let some air out. And reinflate it when you get back home.

But that‚Äôs only my wild guess, from watching thin plastic water bottles as I drive to lower elevations all the time.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-02-08T19:47:44.952Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":239,"readers_count":238,"score":77.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":402473,"topic_slug":"cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure","display_username":"Jim Forbes","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6260,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure/402473/8","custom_user_title":"Jim Forbes 1726 Mechanical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3004885,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-02-08T20:04:27.067Z","cooked":"
gerthworm:

Would atmospheric pressure at different alititudes come into play here?

Going off what the user in this post explained, it sounds like it most certainly would/will.

Cargo dynamics General Forum
Team 4153 builds robots at 7200 ft (2200 m) above sea level. Real tennis balls are crazy bouncy at our elevation, in fact they sell high altitude tennis balls (or used to). We‚Äôre going to have to study how to best simulate sea level bouncy cargo (we‚Äôre part of the Texas Districts and never play at our altitude). Guess I‚Äôll assign that task to our tennis playing members Drives us crazy every time there‚Äôs a game piece which is an inflated ball of some sort. (Bumpers squish/shrink s‚Ä¶
","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-02-08T20:04:27.067Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":225,"readers_count":224,"score":50.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":402473,"topic_slug":"cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/cargo-dynamics/399200/14","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Cargo dynamics","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure/402473/9","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3004904,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-08T20:38:43.395Z","cooked":"
gerthworm:

Or, maybe asked differently‚Ä¶ does the spec‚Äôed inflation PSI refer to some absolute measurement that won‚Äôt vary as altitude/weather changes, or is it relative to outside atmospheric pressure?

Definitely the rule means gauge pressure, that is, the pressure in excess of local atmospheric pressure. 3¬Ω psi absolute pressure would cause the CARGO to collapse into a bowl shape at sea level.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-02-08T20:38:43.395Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":201,"readers_count":200,"score":45.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":402473,"topic_slug":"cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure/402473/10","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3004917,"name":"aidanw02","username":"aidanw02","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aidanw02/{size}/167211_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-08T20:54:38.452Z","cooked":"

We are just trying to figure out how much variation to account for. At this point I would think cargo would mostly be shrinking due to lowering pressure. If it doesn‚Äôt grow much past 2 psi, then I would think they won‚Äôt over expand much throughout the competition.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-02-08T20:54:38.452Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":48.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":402473,"topic_slug":"cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure","display_username":"aidanw02","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":2254,"username":"waialua359","name":"waialua3:59","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/waialua359/{size}/676_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33001,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cargo-actual-diameter-at-pressure/402473/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3004933,"name":"Fields","username":"Fields","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fields/{size}/7873_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-08T21:44:32.241Z","cooked":"

We‚Äôre getting +/- 0.25"

Also, we intentionally inflated one to 10 psi for over a week now. Still only ~0.25" larger than the normal ball. It does have a noticeable firmness to it and it bounces about 6-8" higher with the test drop.

We got our pressure gauge today and filled one of the cargo balls to pressure. I noticed when measuring it this time that it‚Äôs not perfectly round. Not that I‚Äôm surprised by this, but just thought it would be good to mention. This could be why some people are getting different diameters. To measure ours I set it on a table and used a height gauge. I was getting heights from 9.20" to 9.40".

Also FYI, in the manual for the digital gauge we got, it has you zero the pressure first so that it‚Äôs set for you altitude.
